div1.head: Explanation of the symbols used in this edition in recording various readings.
div1.p: As a general rule, wherever the text (that of W. Dindorf's fourth Edition, as revised by Blass in 1889) agrees with that of the Zurich editors, I have not thought it necessary to notice any variations in the MSS. Where Dindorf differs from the Zurich editors, the difference is in most cases due to the greater weight given by the latter to the readings of the Paris MS S.
Z stands for the Zürích text of Demosthenes as printed by J. G. Barter and H Sauppe in their excellent edition of the Oratores Attici, in one volume (1850).

‘Bekker st.’ is Bekker's stereotyped edition published at Leipzig in 1854. The readings adopted in his Berlin ed. 1824 have been occasionally recorded. When Dindorf differs from the Zurich editors, he generally agrees with Bekker. When a note begins with Bekk., it is meant that Dindorf's text is supported by Bekker's Berlin and Leipzig editions: then, after a slight space, follows the reading of the Zurich editors (Z) with the MSS supporting it, introduced by the word cum.
The MSS thus quoted by the Zurich editors are as follows:

S (or *s) in the Bibliothèque Nationale, Paris (No. 2934), on parchment; of century X. This is admitted on all hands to be the best MS, and its readings are very often accepted by Bekker and still more frequently by the Zürich editors. (For a protest against excessive deference to its authority, see the Preface of Mr Shilleto's fourth edition of the De falsa legatione, pp. vii, viii, xiv.) It was published in facsimile in 1893, Paris (Leroux).
F. Codex Marcianus (No. 416), in the Library of St Mark's, Venice, on parchment; of century XI. The best MS of the second group or family (Dindorf), but closely followed by the Codex Bavaricus (B).
Q (or *f). In the same Library (No. 418), on parchment; of century XI.
r. In the Bibliothèque Nationale, Paris (No. 2936), on parchment forma maxima; of century XIII.

A (or A{1}). Augustanus primus, formerly at Augsburg (Augusta Vindelicorum), now at Munich (No. 485), on parchment, paene quadratus; of century XI (according to Dindorf), or XII (according to the Zürich editors).
B. Bavaricus, now at Munich (No. 85), on cotton-paper (‘bombycinus’), forma maxima; of century XIII
gr. A contraction for gra/fetai, used in the MSS themselves to introduce the marginal citation of a various reading.

div2.p:
THIS oration, like those against Zenothemis, Lacritus, and Dionysodorus, is on the subject of bottomry, or a loan of money made on the security of a ship or a cargo or both, and either for the outer voyage only or the return-voyage also, as agreed upon. These transactions were very numerous at Athens, and chiefly on account of the trade in corn. The risk was great, and therefore the interest demanded was large, the lender in fact charging a rate that would cover insurance besides leaving a good profit for the use of the money
The student will do well to read carefully the ninth chapter, Book I of Boeckh's ‘Public Economy,’ on the Foreign Trade of Attica, and also the twentythird of the same Book, on Loans upon Bottomry. [Cf. K. F. Hermann, Privatalterthümer, p. 459 ed. Blümner; Büchsenschütz, Besitz und Erwerb, pp. 486—490; and Smith's Dict. of Ant. s.v. Fenus, i 833{3}. S.].

The case in this oration is quite simple. Chrysippus lent Phormion, a merchant or trader, 20 minae (about £80) for a voyage to Bosporus (in the Crimea) and back (§ 6). The contract required Phormion, when he had sold his cargo of goods at the mart there, to take on board a return-cargo, from the profits of which, or of both, he was to repay the loan with interest at thirty per cent.
at Athens. But being unable to sell his wares in Bosporus, he desired the skipper, Lampis, to sail back to Athens without him, promising that he would soon follow. It so happened that Lampis' ship was wrecked; and though Phormion, having no goods on board, was not in any way a loser by the accident, he evaded his liability by falling back on a clause in the contract, which exempted him from payment if his ship failed to come in safe to the Peiraeus. It is on this point that the action turns. Chrysippus gives evidence that Phormion never thought of disputing his liability at first, on his return to Athens, but trumped up the excuse at a subsequent time in collusion with Lampis.

Chrysippus then brings an action, of the class called e)mporikai\ di/kai, to compel Phormion to pay his claims. Phormion objects that the suit cannot be maintained, because he has done nothing to violate the terms of the contract. This objection is now answered by Chrysippus. The speech is accordingly directed against the paragrafh/ or special plea which had been put in by Phormion, and shows grounds why the action can be and ought to be tried.

The liability to pay had been at first admitted by Phormion: but he afterwards denied it, and when the case was submitted to arbitration by mutual consent (§ 18) he had suborned Lampis (who on a former occasion had, virtually at least, admitted that he had not been paid anything by Phormion) to swear that he had received the money from him in Bosporus, and had lost it in the ship which had been wrecked. Chrysippus handles the accounts in a very dexterous way, and convicts Phormion of falsehood by showing that the money he pretended to have paid Lampis was a great deal too much. He dwells also on the improbability of so large a sum having been paid without any witness to the
transaction, and urges that the clause in the contract, making the safety of the ship a condition of the liability, must be taken in close connexion with another clause, which compels the borrower to put goods on board for the home voyage; which Phormion had been unable to do.

The paragrafh/, or special plea, might have been put in, says Chrysippus, if the transaction had not been made in, or in connexion with, the Attic mart. But the law is explicit in stating (§ 42) that all disputes about contracts so made shall be brought before the Attic courts. And the defence set up, viz. that the money was paid, is not a ground for a special plea at all; it is simply a defence in an ordinary action (eu)qudiki/a).

The Phormion in this suit pro\s *formi/wna is quite a distinct person from the Phormion in Or. 36, u(pe\r *formi/wnos, who was a liberated slave, and concerned in a banking transaction. [In the present speech it would appear that neither Phormion nor Chrysippus was a citizen of Athens; like Lampis, the skipper, probably both of the litigants were me/toikoi.]

The date of the speech is approximately fixed by the mention of Paerisades in § 8, as king of Bosporus, which office he held from B.C. 348 to 310, and also by the allusion in § 38 to the capture of Thebes by Alexander, B.C. 335. [The famine-prices of § 34 belong to the years 330—29 and 328—7. Thus the speech belongs to the year 327—6. The late date and the general style of the speech have led the majority of modern critics to deny that it was written by Demosthenes.]

[Modern Literature. Arnold Schaefer, Demosthenes und seine Zeit, III B 300—306, 1858. Blass, die Attische Beredsamkeit, III i 515—520{1}, 1877; 576—582{2}. 1893. Also the following Dissertations: — (1) A. Baumstark, Prolegomenorum in orationem Dem. adv. Phormionem caput prius, sive de litigantium personis ac statu civili commentatio
(Heidelberg) 1826. (2) I. Hermann, Einleitende Bemerkungen zu Demosthenes paragraphischen Reden (Or. 32—38), pp. 9—13 (Erfurt) 1853. (3) R. Duncker, inter privatarum causarum orationes Demosthenicas quae pro genuinis habendae sint quaeque pro falsis breviter exponitur. pp. 12—17 (Greiffenberg i. Pomm.) 1877. (4) P. Uhle, Quaestiones de orationum Demostheni falso addictarum scriptoribus, ii, de orat. xxxiii, xxxiv, lvi scriptoribus (Leipzig) 1886. (5) Th. Thalheim, der Process des Chrysippos gegen Phormion, ([Dem.]) Or. xxxiv; pp. 58—68 of Philologische Abhandlungen Martin Hertz...dargebracht (Berlin) 1888. (6) W. H. Kirk, (a) Johns Hopkins University Circular, no. 109, Feb. 1894; and (b) Demosthenic Style in the Private Orations, pp. 36—38 (Baltimore) 1895.]

pro\s *formi/wna peri\ danei/ou The speech is quoted under the same title in Pollux ix 45 e)n tw=| pro\s *formi/wna peri\ danei/ou. Harpocration, however, in explaining the use of e)peqh/kamen in § 28, s. v. e)piqe/tous e(orta/s, gives the fuller and more accurate title u(pe\r *xrusi/ppou pro\s th\n *formi/wnos paragrafh/n, which is also found at the end of the speech in the Paris MS, and at the beginning in the Augustanus primus. Harpocr. s. v. e)/fektos to/kos, quoted on § 23, has the shorter title e)n tw=| u(pe\r *xrusi/ppou. S.]

Argument. kate/laben k.t.l. ‘He found there was no market for the wares he was bringing.’ What these were, does not appear. Probably it was a mixed cargo on speculation. He called it r(w=pos, ‘trash,’ in a fit of ill-temper at his failure, in § 9.

forti/wn w(=n e)ko/mize This is an instance of attraction to an antecedent which is expressed, whereas the usage is much more common when the antecedent is omitted, and the case of the word to be supplied is shifted as it were on to the relative, by which the ellipse is sufficiently indicated. This attraction takes place only where the proper case of the relative is the accusative. We may say kata/logos bibli/wn w(=n e)/xomen or a(\ e)/xomen, but not w(=n xrw)meqa, because w(=n may represent a(/, but not oi(=s.

ibid. nauklh/rou ‘The skipper.’ The word seems properly to mean one who has a share or interest in a ship; a part-owner, or one who has hired it for a time (Phot. in v.). Hesych, explains it by o( despo/ths tou= ploi/ou. [Lampis, however, was only a freedman, representing his former master. Cf. Lacrit. § 33 (marturi/ai) *(ublh/sios e)n auklh/rei ...koinwnei=n de\ kai\ au)to\s th=s news *(ublhsiw|, kai\ sumplei=n e(autou= oi)ke/tas en th=| nhi). A. Schaefer, Dem. u. seine Zeit (III B 305), quotes Bekker's Anecdota, p. 282, nau/klhros shmai/nei me
 kai\ to

th=s new\s ku/rion, shmai/nei de\ kai\ to
 e/piple/onta au)th=| e)f' w)=| ta\ nau=la lamba/nein. S.]
ta\ a)gora/smata The goods purchased with, or in place of (i.e. as security for), the money he had borrowed from Chrysippus.
a)rgu/rion The money he ought to have made by the transaction, and given to Lampis to hand over to Chrysippus on his return.
e)n tw=| le/mbw| Lampis, with a few others (some thirty being lost, § 10), gets safe to land in the ship's boat.
a)paitou/menos ‘On being asked for payment.’ [For a)paitei=n, rem debitam reposcere, cf. § 12 and note on Or. 53 § 10. For the passive of the person, cf. Xen. Apol. 17 a)paitei=sqai eu)ergesi/an. S.]

th\n ga\r suggrafh\n ‘The compact expressly says that if anything happens to the ship at sea, Phormion is discharged from his debt to Chrysippus.’ Loans on bottomry partook of the nature of insurance also, i.e. the profit on the loan was so large (§ 23), that it covered some total losses resulting from wrecks or loss of goods from pirates, storms, or other unavoidable mishaps.
paregra/yato Phormion put in a demurrer or bar to the suit, trying to show there was no ground for action at all, as he had kept the terms of the contract.

para\ tw=| diaithth=| Lampis had given false testimony when the case was brought before the
arbitrator, Theodotus, § 18, for he had been bribed by Phormion to say anything to get him off. It appears from § 18 that a witness was not likely to be prosecuted for yeudomarturi/a given before an arbitrator.

e)nte/qeiken This perfect is one of the middle-Attic forms. It occurs first in Eur. El. 7 u(yhlw=n d' e)pi\ nhw=n te/qeike sku=la plei=sta barba/rwn, with which compare parei=ken, the perfect of pari/hmi, in Hel. 1059. a)feiko/ta occurs Or. 37 § 1.
e)cesthke/nai That he was out of his sober senses—not himself, as we say. [ou)k e)nto\s w)\n au)tou=, §§ 20, 35, 49. Eur. Bacch. 359 me/mhnas h)/dh kai\ pri\n e)ce/sths frenw=n. S.]
ibid. e)kei=na ‘that other account.’

mhde\n a)pofhna/menos ‘Without delivering judgment.’ In classical Greek, of course, ou)de\n would be required. Cf. o(/ti mh\ inf. 39.—pe/pomfe, a rather rare perfect (Thuc. VII 12). Perhaps pepo/mfei, or e)pepo/mfei, ‘had sent.’ Otherwise we should expect the aorist. In this late Greek the Latin usage, which has one tense only for aorist and perfect, misit, is perhaps incorrectly followed. See Winer's Grammar, p. 136 ed. Moulton. Cf. Or. 39, Arg. § 2 teteleu/thken. [Mr F. H. Baynes defends this use of the perfect, regarding it as=pe/pomfen h)/dh, i.e. the position of affairs now, at the moment of the delivery of the present speech, is this, that the arbitrator has sent the case before the court.]

th\n eu)qei=an gi/gnetai It takes the course of an ordinary or regular action, eu)qudiki/a. The accusative here is strangely and irregularly used, and perhaps para\ should be retained, ‘according to the ordinary practice.’ In showing that a special plea cannot be urged in this case, Chrysippus, or his advocate, goes into all the facts, just as they would appear in a common trial.

e)pishmai/netai ‘Remarks’; another late usage,—kat' a)rxa\s, see § 4.—to\ le/gein, ‘the saying a man has done all the contract required him to do is no ground at all for pleading that the action cannot be brought.’ ‘That (he says) is the plea of one who is defendant in an ordinary trial, and rebuts a charge brought against him; not the plea of
one who wants to show that there is no case against him at all.’ A paragrafh/, in fact, turned solely on the inadmissibility of a suit, e.g. on the ground that it belonged to another court or different jurisdiction. He quotes as a case of this in the next sentence, that contracts not made at or for a voyage to Athens could not be brought before an Athenian court.

teth/rhtai ‘The same peculiarity is observed here as in the speech against Neaera, viz. that it is not spoken by one party only; but whereas there the division is plain, here it is confused and obscure: it appears to me however’ (i.e. to the grammarian Libanius) ‘that the second speech begins at a)kou/sas, &c (§ 21, where see note). Anyhow, it is clear that they are partners who bring this action against Phormion.’

p. 907. §§ 1, 2. The proeme, or introduction. Chrysippus begins by showing that he and his partner are reasonable men, who can bear a loss if it is a just and unavoidable one, and not sukofa/ntai or lovers of law.

e)n tw=| me/rei ‘In our turn,’ and at a disadvantage, because they had been abused and misrepresented in every way. Phormion,
the party accused, in pleading a demurrer, had the first speech; consequently the actual plaintiffs, Chrysippus and partner, speak after him. This is the meaning of kathgorei=n tou= diw/kontos in § 4. See Or. 45 § 6.

Kennedy renders it, ‘as we take our turns of addressing you,’— apparently referring it to the two partners speaking in succession. But this appears a less likely meaning. [Kennedy's rendering was disapproved by Shilleto. Blass (Att. Ber. III i 578{2}) suggests that the view that the two partners spoke ‘in turns’ may have partly arisen from a misunderstanding of e)n tw=| me/rei. If this phrase refers to successive speeches by the two partners, he would expect e(kate/rou h(mw=n, rather than h(mw=n, or e)n me/rei, ‘by turns.’ rather than e)n tw=| me/rei, ‘in our turn.’ He adds that e)n me/rei, ‘in turn,’ occurs in Aesch. Eum. 198, 436, 586. It may be added that e)n me/rei is also found in Dem. 2 § 24, Aeschin. 2 § 41, 3 § 4, Isocr. 4 §§ 96, 164; and e)n tw=| me/rei in Thuc. iv 11 a)napau/ontes e)n tw=| m. tou\s e)pi/plous e)poiou=nto, viii 86 tw=n pentakisxili/wn pa/ntes e)n tw=| m. meqe/cousi, Xen. Anab. III 4 § 23 e)n tw=| m. (‘in their turn’) oi( loxagoi\ die/bainon (of the 6 loxagoi\ and their 600 picked men, in contrast to the rest of the hoplites), Plato Symp. 198 C u(mi=n w(molo/goun e)n tw=| m. meq' u(mw=n e)gkwmia/sesqai to\n e)/rwta, 199 A w(molo/ghsa kai\ au)to\s e)n tw=| m. e)paine/sesqai, Gorg. 474 A e)moi\ e)n tw=| m. para/dos, 462 A, and Phileb. 50 E. In all these cases the article has a possessive sense. The passages from Thuc. imply consecutive succession, but all the rest imply contrast with a predecessor and to some extent support the interpretation preferred by Paley, Shilleto, and Blass. S.]
i)diw=tai Unprofessional as far as the art of speaking is concerned. [Isocr. Paneg. § 11 tw=n lo/gwn toi=s u(pe\r tou\s i)diw/tas e)/xousi kai\ li/an a)phkribwme/nois, and ib. § 44 n. S.]

polu\n xro/non k.t.l. ‘Long as we have been frequenting your mart (i e. the Peiraeus), and many as are the merchants with whom we have had transactions about loans, we have never yet commenced any suit either as plaintiffs or defendants; and even now, be well assured, if we had really thought the money that we lent to Phormion had been lost on the ship that was wrecked, we should not have brought this action against him: no! we are not so shameless nor so inexperienced in losses.’
ei)s—ei)safiknou/menoi Or. 35 § 2 pollw=n a)fiknoume)nwn ei)s to\ u(me/teron e)mpo/rion.
sumbo/laia Contracts or mutual compacts, especially in matters of money or commerce. See Or. 37 § 49, and 33 § 3 o(/sa e)moi\ kai\ tou/tw| e)ge/neto sumbo/. laia.

ou)d' a)
—ou(k k.t.l. In this sentence the ou)k is superfluously repeated after the ou)de\, by a not very common idiom. We might have expected kai\ nu=n—ou)k a)/n pote e)la/xomen k.t.l., but the negative sentence is continued, ou)demi/an pw/pote di/khn ei)sh/lqomen, ou)d' a)
 nu=n—e/la)xomen, and the second ou)k is added before the verb in order to carry the favourite combination ou)k a)
. the simple verb e)la/xomen being too far removed from the preceding ou)d' a)
 nu=n. Compare Mid. § 129 ou)d' ei) to\ par) a)mfote/rwn h(mw=n u(/dwr u(pa/rceie,—ou)k a)
 e)carke/seien. Not unlike this is Or. 37 § 59 ou)de/ ge a)
 o( paqw
 au)to\s a)fh=|—ou)deni\ tw=n loipw=n suggenw=n e)/cestin e/pecie/nai. There is another instance in Or. 22 (Androt.) § 32 e)n tai=s o)ligarxi/ais, ou)d' a)
 w)=sin e)/t) *)androti/wno/s tines ai)/sxion bebiwko/tes, ou)k e)/sti le/gein kakw=s tou\s a)/rxontas. In other cases (Or. 37 § 16) the ou)de\ placed at the beginning negatives the whole sentence. See also Mid. § 57.
a)kribw=s i)/ste Cf. 56 § 9. Inf. § 35 a). mnhmoneu/ein, 56 § 33 a). manqa/nein (Uhle, p. 28).

kakizo/ntwn ‘Taunting us with cowardice,’ i.e. with the fear of being called sukofa/ntai. So Or. 54 § 5 loidorhqe/ntos au)toi=s e/kei/nou kai\ kaki/santos au)tou/s. Mid. § 73 oi(\ to\n me\n kakiei=n oi(=s e)/prace— e)/mellon.
*bospo/rw| [Also called Panticapaeum (Kertsch), Lacrit. § 31, the capital of the Bosporus Cimmerius. Cf. Dem. Lept. Or. 20 §§ 29—36. S.] See the note on Or. 35 § 10.
to\ mh\ bohqh=sai Not to seek redress; not to do all we could to assist our own cause, by appearing in person. The word is often used in appealing to the law or the judges.

§§ 3, 4. Phormion's plea for a paragrafh/, i.e. his ground for denying that the action can be tried, is this: ‘I don't deny that the contract was made in your market (your Exchange, we should say), but I deny that, after the shipwreck, I am any
longer bound by the contract. But that plea is no real ground: the law says, ‘an action cannot be tried if the compact was not made at Athens, nor for the Athenian market’; which does not hold in this case. His defence, in fact, is only applicable to an ordinary trial, eu)qudiki/a, in which the action solely depends on the merits of the case.
kai\ ga\r ou)=toi ‘For even the defendants,’ i.e. Phormion and Lampis.
ou)ke/ti—sumbo/laion ‘No contract still subsisting against them’ (Kennedy).

oi( me/ntoi no/moi k.t.l. Cf. Or. 32 (Zenoth.) § 1 oi( no/moi keleu/ousin. ta\s di/kas ei)=nai toi=s nauklh/rois kai\ toi=s e)mpo/rois tw=n *)aqh/naze kai\ tw=n *)aqh/nhqen sumbolai/wn, kai\ peri\ w(=n a)
 w)=si suggrafai/: a)
 de/ tis para\ tau=ta dika/zhtai, mh\ ei)sagw/gimon ei)=nai th
 di/khn. S.]
a)mfisbhth=| ‘should contend (raise the question, urge the point) on the other side that he has done all that the contract required.’
ou) kathgorei=n See on § 1, e)n tw=| me/rei.

ou) mh\n a)lla\ k.t.l. ‘Not but that I hope’—lit. ‘I do not however (dwell on this point, viz. what is the true ground of a paragrafh/), but I hope,’ &c. Translate: ‘Still I hope to show from the facts of the case itself that this suit of mine is one that can be tried. And now observe well what is admitted by the defendants themselves, and what is denied; for by these means you will best investigate the truth of my charges.’

[ou) mh\n a)lla\ here introduces an argument a fortiori. The speaker has already said that the demurrer is bad in law. He now says; ‘nay, but (granting that they have in law a right to put in a special plea, yet even so) I hope to show that the action may still be brought, their allegation being false in fact. I will prove from the facts of the case that, supposing their plea to be admissible, it cannot help them. It is indeed worse than
inadmissible, it is false if admitted.’ F. H. Baynes.]
sunqh/kas poih/sasqai ‘They had contracts duly made to secure the loan.’
fasi\ d' a)podedwke/nai to\ xrusi/on repeated with slight variations in §§ 9, 11, 14—17, 22— 26, 29, 33—35, 41, 46, 47 (Uhle, p. 18).]

ou)d' h)=n au)tw=| ‘That he could not have paid,’ since he could not realize the value of his wares, § 8. [h)=n makes better sense than e)ch=n, rendered by Kennedy, ‘it was not even lawful for him to pay.’]
§§ 6, 7. Statement of the circumstances and nature of the loan, and of the way in which Phormion violated it at the very first by illegal acts.

e)gw\ ga\r k.t.l. ‘I on my part lent the defendant twenty minae’ (about £80), ‘for the double voyage to Pontus and back, on the security of twice that amount of goods.’ The meaning of e)pi\ e(te/ra| u(poqh/kh| has been doubted; but the context leaves it pretty clear that it is a brief legal term for ef' e(te)rw| tosou/tw|. Cf. Or. 35 § 18 e)danei/zonto par' h(mw=n ta\s tria/konta mna=s, w(s uparxou/shs au)toi=s u(poqh/khs e(te/rwn tria/konta mnw=n. Phormion borrowed 20 minae = 2000 drachmae, and should have put on board goods worth 4000 drachmae, this transaction leaving an ample margin for a bad market, or for actual losses. Mr Joseph Bickersteth Mayor (in The Journal of Philology VI p. 242) thinks the phrase means ‘on a separate, distinct, independent security,’ and to this he refers ou)/te ga\r th\n u(poqh/khn pare/sxeto (pare/sxen) in § 7, and u(poqh/khn ou)k e)/xwn in § 22. Would not this be e)p' a)/llh u(poqh/kh|? (Compare however e(f' e(te/ras new\s in § 9.) If the goods (of whatever amount) were the security, and (what is
nowhere expressly stated, though it seems probable) the ship itself also was pledged, the not bringing the ship back to the Peiraeus would be alluded to in § 7. Kennedy follows Seager in rendering it ‘on the security of the single cargo,’ i.e. the return cargo; but it does not appear how the Greek can mean this.

[Thalheim, der Process des Chrysippos, p. 59, explains it thus: ‘fur das Darlelin wird ausser der dafur zu beschaffenden Ladung eine weitere Ladung von 20m verpfandet’; and M. Dareste renders it: ‘avec affectation sur un chargement d'une valeur double’; thereby coinciding with Mr Paley's view, which, however, says Shilleto, ‘cannot be right.’ Mr Page suggests that the phrase is a technical term used when a borrower gives security equal in amount to the sum lent. On this view it is the difference between the sum lent and the goods purchased that constitutes the real security. Possibly the phrase should be altered into e)p' e)leuqe/ra| u(poqh/kh|, ‘or an unencumbered security’; cf. Or. 35 § 21 u(potiqe/asi tau=t' e)leu/qera and § 22 e/p' e)leuqe/rois toi=s xrh/masi daneizo/menoi. But, even in an early papyrus (Greek Papyri ii 20, Grenfell and Hunt), we here find epi etera, as in our ordinary MSS. S.]

a)mfotero/ploun sc. da/neion, ‘For the double voyage,’ as e(tero/plous (§ 22) is for the single or outer voyage. See Or. 56 §§ 6 and 29. It was usual in the latter case to pay the loan and interest either to a partner on the spot, under letter of advice, or to an agent who was on board during the voyage.

e)qe/mhn ‘I deposited the bond with Kittus the banker.’ [Possibly son of the Kittus mentioned in the trapezitiko\s of Isocr. as a servant of the noted banker Pasion. S.] It was the custom then, as with us, to place valuable deeds in the custody of bankers. See Or. 33 § 15; 35 § 14.
keleuou/shs—suggrafh=s § 7 ad fin.
pra=gma poiei= pa/ntwn Alliterative. Cf. 37 § 48 piqanwta/tw| pa/ntwn . .kai\ ponhrota/tw|. S.]

eu)qu\s ‘At the very outset,’ before he left the harbour.— e)pidanei/zetai, ‘he raises another loan on the same security.’ This was illegal, as a second mortgage would be on property already mortgaged to its full value. Or. 35 § 21 meta\ de\ tau=t' e)/stin e)n th=| suggrafh=| o(/ti u(potiqe/asi tau=t) e)leu/qera kai\ ou)deni\ ou)de\n o)fei/lontes.
*qeodw/rou ‘La traduction grecque du nom phénicien Ionathan ou Nathaniel, ou du nom carthaginois Baalitan ou Mathanélim.’ Dareste. S.]

tou= *foi/nikos ‘The Phoenician.’ [The Phoenicians of Tyre and Sidon carried on a considerable trade with Greece (Odyss. xv 415—480) and many of that mercantile people were settled in Athens. There is a decree extant granting the Sidonians resident in Athens exemption from the metoi/kion and other taxes. Cf. Isocr. Trapez. § 4 susth/santo/s moi *puqodw/rou tou= *foi/nikos *pasi/wna, e)xrw/mhn th=| tou/tou trape/zh|, and Buchsenschutz, Besitz und Erwerb im Griechischen Alterthume, pp. 443, 275, 362. S.]
katagora/sai The word technically means ‘to purchase goods against, or as a set-off to, a sum of money.’

mnw=n e(kato\n k.t.l. [If the terms of the agreements with Theodorus and Lampis were identical with those of the original agreement with Chrysippus, Phormion was bound to put on board not 115 minae (as the MSS have it), but 150, i.e. double the value of the three loans, amounting in all to 7500 dr. = 75 minae. The copyist may have failed to understand what more than one critic has conjectured as the right reading, viz. 150 minae. He was possibly led to alter this into 115, on finding that the latter happened to be the total of the sums mentioned in the text. He thus makes the blunder of including the original loan of 20 minae in the estimated total value of the goods which should have been put on board.
e)da/neisa ei)/kosi mna=s = 2000 dr.
keleu/ei h( suggrafh\) e/nqe/sqai tetrakisxi-) = 4000 dr. li/wn forti/a a)/cia ...)
para\ *qeodw/ron. .... = 4500 dr.
para\ *la/mpidos...... = 1000 dr.
mnai= e(kato\n deka/pente = 11,500 dr.

The MS reading (= 11,500 dr.) is, however, retained by Boeckh, P. E. I xxiii 169{3} (185 Lamb), and by Thalheim, u. s., p. 60. They hold that the terms of the three contracts were not necessarily identical. While Chrysippus and his brother, who stayed at Athens, required, for
a loan of 2000 dr. on the double voyage, the double security of a cargo worth 4000 dr., Theodorus and Lampis, who went on board the ship themselves (§ 26), may have required for a loan of 5,500 dr. on the single voyage, the security of a cargo worth 7,500 dr. or only 2000 dr. more than their loan. S.]
ou) kathgo/rasen k.t.l. ‘He did not buy goods of the value of more than 5500 dr.’
a)ll' h)\ [Used only after an actual or an implied negative. S.] Originally, it seems to have represented a)/llo or a)/lla h)/.
su\n i.e. including the provisions for the crew, which should have been paid for in addition.

[Except in Xenophon, meta\ with Gen. is far more frequent in Attic Prose than su
 with Dat. In Dem. the ratio is 22:1. The latter is mainly found in certain set phrases, e.g. 19 § 155 su
 qeoi=s ei)pei=n, and (as in the text) in the sense including (of the items of an account or any other enumeration), 27 §§ 23, 35, 61 su
 toi=s a)rxai/ois, ‘including the principal,’ 27 § 50 and 28 § 13 su
 toi=s e)/rgois, ‘including the interest,’ 27 § 31 su
 sidh/rw|, 27 § 38 su
 tai=s e)bdomh/konta mnai=s, 35 (Lacrit.) § 18 su
 toi=s a)nalw/masin, 31 § 11 su
 oi(=s pro/teron e)zhmi/wto, 19 § 155 su
 ai(=s e)poreu/qhmen o(mou= penth/konq' o(/las (h(me/ras). su
 is also found in tmesis, su
 eu)= peponqw/s (twice in 8 § 65 and in [10] § 67). The above are all the examples in the Demosthenic speeches. Cf. Tycho Mommsen, Griech. Praepositionen 1895, pp. 356, 370 f., 375. S.]
o)fei/lei Heowes 7500 drachms to the three lenders, viz. 2000 +4500+1000 = 7500 = 75 minae.

th\n u(poqh/khn It seems from § 50, that the penalty of death attached to the not producing or handing over the security. In this case, either the ship might have been made over to Chrysippus, or double the value of his loan put on board. Phormion did neither, as all the goods on board only covered the value of the e)pidaneismoi/.
ou)/te — nau=n Repeated with variations in §§ 9—11, 16, 17, 20, 22, 27, 33, 34, 40 (Uhle, p. 18).]

a)pografh(n The entry made by the collectors of the two percent. duties on all exports and imports. In the time of the Peloponnesian war these tolls seem to have been less; for we read of ta\s polla\s e(katosta\s in Ar. Vesp. 658. [Cf., however, Boeckh, P. E. III v p. 321 Lewis (=p. 429 Lamb):—‘We are not justified in assuming that this hundredth was an import duty, which was levied at a particular period in place of the fiftieth; for we find the fiftieth mentioned both in the earlier time of Andocides (whose lease of the custom duties... falls in the first years after the anarchy), and also in the time of Demosthenes; and an alteration in this tax cannot be assumed without any proof.’ Boeckh conjectures that the e(katosth\ was a harbour duty, separate from the custom duty or penthkosth/. Cf. Gilbert's Gk. Const. Ant., p. 350 ET. S.]

§§ 8, 9. Arrived at Bosporus (Panticapaeum) he again acted fraudulently in not delivering the advices I had written to my agent there, which were, that he should keep his eye on Phormion. And at last, being unable to sell his goods, and finding it difficult to pay the e)pidaneismoi/ (which he had borrowed only for the outer voyage), instead of shipping goods from the Euxine to Athens, as he was bound to do by his contract with me, he told Lampis to set out for Athens, and promísed that he would follow on another ship.

a(\s e)/dwka ‘Which I had given him to deliver to a servant of mine who was wintering there, and a certain partner.’ It might seem doubtful whether paidi\ means ‘son’ or ‘servant,’ but we have ou)/te to
 pai=da to
 h(me/teron ou)/te to
 koinwno
 § 28, *la/mpidi tw=| *di/wnos oi)ke/th| § 5, and meta\ tw=n a)/llwn pai/dwn tw=n *di/wnos inf. § 10.
paraxeima/zonti Or. 56 § 30.
th\n u(poqh/khn viz. that the security was the cargo, and therefore that a counter-cargo must be sent from the Euxine back to Athens.

e)peida\n ta/xista § 11; Or. 56 § 11. ‘As soon as ever the goods were (shall have been) unloaded, that he should take stock (inventory) of them and keep close to him,’ viz. lest he should give him the slip. This use of e)ceta/zein is idiomatic. See
Ar. Eccl. 728 e)gw\ d' , i(/n) ei)s a)gora/n ge ta\ skeu/h fe/rw, proxeiriou=mai ka)ceta/sw th\n ou)si/an. Kennedy's rendering ‘to inspect’ does not fully give the sense.

katalabw\n—a)prasi/an ‘Finding business in Bosporus bad, through the war that had broken out between Paerisades and the Scythian (king), and great difficulty in selling the goods he had brought.’ Paerisades is mentioned inf. § 36 as an ally and friend of Athens. He is identical with a king of that name who is said by Diodorus Siculus (XVI ch. 52 fin.) to have reigned in Pontus Ol. 107,4 (B.C. 349—8); a(/ma de\ tou/tois prattome/nois e)n tw=| *po/ntw| *spa/rtakos o( tou= *po/ntou basileu)s e)teleu/thsen a)/rcas e)/th pe/nte, th\n d' h(gemoni/an diadeca/menos o( a)delfo\s *parisa/dhs e)basi/leus en e)/th tria/konta o)ktw/. Again, in lib. xx ch. 22 and 24 we have mention of *parusa/dhs as basileu\s tou= *kimmerikou= *bospo/rou, B.C. 310, and of a grandson of the same name, o( pai=s o( *satu/rou *parusa/dhs. Strabo (VII 4 § 4) speaks of Leucon, Satyrus, and Paerisades as mo/narxoi of Panticapaeum, and says the last had divine honours paid to him. He mentions a *pairisa/dhs o( u(/statos who gave up his kingdom to Mithridates. [Paerisades, king of Bosporus (B.C. 348— 310), is the Birisides of Dinarchus in Dem. § 43 (compare infr. § 36 n.), but is different from Berisades, king of Thrace, who, as may be seen from Dem. Aristocr. § 10, was already dead in B.C. 352. Penrose has apparently confounded them.— For a dissertation on the Kings of Bosporus, see Clinton, Fasti Hellenici II, Appendix, chap. 13, and cf. Grote, chap. 99. S.]

to
 *sku/qhn ‘the Scythian (king)’; 5 § 25 to
 *ka=ra, 23 § 133 to
 *qra=|ka. Cf. Ol. 1 § 23.]
a)prasi/an § 22 a)prasi/an tw=n forti/wn kate/labe.
oi( daneistai\ viz. Theodorus and Lampis.—kai\ ga)r, i.e. they also, besides the other demands on him to ship a cargo for Athens.
ta\ a)gora/smata The goods bought with, or as a set-off to, my money. Hesych. a)gora/smata) w)/nia. Cf. § 33.
o(/ti ou)k a)\n du/naito k.t.l. His actual words would be, ou)k a)\n dunai/mhn, mh\ diatiqe/menos ta\ forti/a.

to
 r(w=pon ‘the trash,’ ‘the common wares.’ Vilia scruta, Hor. Epist. 17, 65. Aeschylus fragm. *fru/ges (242 Dind.) nauba/thn forthgo
 o(/stis r(w=pon e)ca/gei xqono/s. [Strabo VIII p. 376 says of Aegina: e)mpo/rion ga(r gene/sqai dia\ th
 lupro/thta th=s xw/ras tw=n a)nqrw/pwn qalattourgou/ntwn e)mporikw=s, a)f' ou(= to
 r(w=pon *ai)ginai/an e)mpolh
 le/gesqai. Eustath. on Iliad XIII 199, r(w=pos me/ntoi lepto\s kai\ a)telh\s (qu. eu)telh\s) fo/rtos, w(s de\ *ai)/lios *dionu/sios le/gei, kai\ poiki/los. Bekker's Anecd. 299 r\w=pos o( pantodapo\s fo/rtos. Hesych. r(wpopw=lai: muropw=lai. S.] Hesych. r)w=pos: r\wpiko/n: a)nti\ tou= ou)deno\s a)/cion. o( ga lepto\s r(w=pos, h)/goun o( fo/rtos, mi/gmata, xrwmata, o(sa zwgra/fois, bafeu=si, mureyoi=s xrhsimeu/ei. With this word (mureyoi=s) to
 r(w=pon well agrees, and § 13 katalamba/nomen pro(s toi=s muropwli/ois toutoni/. He may have done a small business in perfumery.

ka)kei=non ‘And Lampis he ordered to put to sea at once, and said that he himself, so soon as he should (shall) have disposed of his wares, would sail out in another ship.’ We have the subjunctive as expressing a result pending at the time described. [Goodwin's Moods and Tenses § 90, ed. 1889. S.]
diati/qesqai precisely our word ‘to dispose of,’ comes naturally from the idea of settling and arranging goods to be kept back or taken away, § 36; Or. 56 § 8. [dia- implies distribution.]

§ 10. Lampis sails while Phormion is left behind. But the ship, being over-freighted, is lost, with some of the crew, and Lampis is picked up in the boat. Evidence is given that Phormion was congratulated for not having any goods on board.
a)naxqei\s Cf. note on Or. 53 (Nicostr.) § 3 a)nh=gmai.

gegemisme/nhs k.t.l. ‘The ship had already been overloaded when Lampis took on deck besides 1000 hides, which was the real cause of the wreck.’ Hides are very heavy; and the deckload would so alter the centre of gravity as to make the ship very unmanageable in a heavy sea. [For the bu/rsai of Bosporus, cf. Lacrit. § 34 (martur.) de/rmata ai)/geia, and Strabo, p. 493 *ta/nai+s kti/sma tw=n to
 *bo/sporon e)xo/ntwn *(ellh/nwn ... e)mpo/rion koino
 tw=n te *)asianw=n kai\ tw=n *eu)rwpai/wn noma/dwn kai\ tw=n e)k tou= *bospo/rou th
 li/mnhn (Sea of Azov) pleo/ntwn tw=n me
 a)ndra/poda a)go/ntwn kai\ de/rmata . .tw=n de\ e)sqh=ta kai\ oi)=non...a)ntifortizome/nwn. S.]
le/mbw| Hesychius has lh/mbwni: e)n skafi/di, h)\ e)n ploiari/w|.

pai/dwn ‘slaves,’ or ‘servants.’ See on § 8. Lampis himself was *di/wnos oi)ke/ths, § 5. tria/konta is much more plausible than the manuscript reading triako/sia (found with sw/mata alone, except in two MSS which add e)leu/qera). By itself triako/sia sw/mata could only be explained on the supposition that it was a slave-ship, bringing *qra=|kes or *sku/qai to Athens (cf. Strabo, supr.). [In later Greek, the use of sw/mata for ‘slaves’ became common, e.g. Revelation xviii 13; Atticists like Pollux (iii 78) protested against this usage, sw/mata a(plw=s ou)k a(\n ei)/pois a)lla\ dou=la sw/mata. Cf. Dem. Lept. § 77 ai)xma/lwta sw/mata. In Plat. Leg. p. 908 A, sw/mata is used of any kind of men, slaves or free, indiscriminately. S.]
xwri\s tw=n a)/llwn ‘besides his cargo.’
pe/nqous ‘mourning,’ the regular meaning of this word

sune/baine—lo/gos i.e. ‘not only so, but we happen to have the same account, and that in the same terms, not only from others but also from Phormion himself.’ sune/baine implies sur
prise that Phormion's own language should agree on this point with the evidence of others. F. H. Baynes.]

§ 11. When I went to Lampis immediately after his arrival in Athens, he declared that Phormion had neither put goods on board the lost vessel nor given him any remittance for Athens. Evidence is adduced of his statement to that effect.
tou/tw|—to\n nou=n repeated in § 23.
e)k th=s n. Either ‘from’ or ‘after’ the wreck.

e)/nqoito Compounds of ti)qesqai and i(/esqai often assume this form of the optative, though MSS commonly present the other form e)nqei=to, e)piqei=to &c. Examples of both are given by Veitch, Irreg. Gk. Verbs, s. v. [Cf. Kuhner-Blass Gr. Gr. ii 194.]
ou)/te to\ xrusi/on The change of subject might have been more clearly expressed by ou)/t' au)to\s to\ xrusi/on k.t.l. [Similar phrases recur in §§ 14, 16, 20, 41, 46, 47, 49.]
tw=n paragenome/nwn Of those present at the interview between me and Lampis at Athens.

§§ 12, 13. And when Phormion himself arrived somewhat later, he told substantially the same story, that is, he admitted his liability. Afterwards, however, there was a collusion between them, and he then said he had paid Lampis the money at Bosporus.

prosh/|ein Like h)/|dein and h)=n, this word takes the n even in the first person in the middle
and later Attic. The older forms were pro/sh|a, h)/|dh, h)=. Similarly kexh/nh is the first person of the pluperfect in Ar. Ach. 10. [Plato Apol. 31 E pa/lai a)\n a)polw/lh kai\ ou)/t' a)\n u(ma=s w)felh/kh k.t.l. Elucidations of Curtius' Gk. Gr. § 283. S.]
o(\n nuni\ le/gei viz. that he paid Lampis.——a)nekoinw/sato, ‘when he had entered into a secret understanding.’

sundikou=sin] sundi/kois ou)=sin, advocates for the defence. Perhaps we should read sunadikou=sin, meaning Lampis in particular. Cf. §§ 28 and 46 *la/mpidos tou= sunadikou=ntos.—parei=nai, adesse, is often used of friends and advocates, e.g. Mid. § 182.
prose/rxomai Cf. proselqo/ntos in § 11, which was the first, this being the second interview.—tw=| *la/mpidi, ‘this Lampis,’ said with some contempt.
proskalesai/mhn inf. prosekalesa/mhn, cf. § 14 proskaloume/nw|...§§ 14, 15 proskalei=.

o( de\ ‘Accordingly he, Lampis, bade me go with him, and we find the defendant at the shops for perfumery.’ See Hesych. quoted on § 9 to\n r(w=pon. [The shops of the perfumers, like those of the barbers and the cobblers, were favourite places of lounge at Athens, cf. Lysias Or. 24 § 20 e(/kastos ga\r u(mw=n ei)/qistai prosfoita=n o( me\n pro\s muropwlei=on, o( de\ pro\s kourei=on, o( de\ pro\s skutotomei=on. S.]

§§ 14, 15. "Though Lampis was present when I served Phormion with a summons, he never said, as he would have done had the story been true, that Phormion had already paid the money to him." A negative argument e)k tw=n ei)ko/twn, as the rhetoricians called it. It was not likely that Lampis would be silent. “Between tekmh/ria and ei)ko/ta there is strictly this difference: the former are the evidentiary facts, the latter the results which are obtained by combining such facts together and reasoning upon them.” Kennedy, Append. VI to Vol. IV of Demosth. p. 369.
So Or. 30 § 10 dh=lon de\ kai\ e)k tw=n ei)ko/twn o(/ti tou/twn e(/nex' w(=n ei)rhka o)fei/lein ei(/lonto.
kai\ o( *la/mpis here (as in § 18) kai\ is loosely used, with kai\ in the previous sentence.]
ei)pei=n Thrice in same §. Cf. ei(pei=n.. ei)=pen in § 15. Similarly ei)ko\s h)=n recurs in §§ 15, 40; also found in 56 § 11.]

mh\ o(/ti Both this and ou)x o(/ti are used in the sense of non modo or non modo non. In the former case there is an ellipse of le/gein, in the latter of le/gw. Translate, ‘Not only did Lampis not utter a word, but not even Phormion himself thought fit to say he had paid it, though Lampis was actually standing by, to whom he now says he paid the money.’ [Cf. Or. 27 § 7; 36 § 39; 43 § 9; 56 § 30. Madvig's Gk. Syntax § 212; Goodwin's Moods and Tenses § 707, ed. 1889.]

ei)ko\s h)=n Lit. ‘it was reasonable for him to have said.’ Hence in such expressions as dikaion h)=n, e)xrh=n, &c, the Greeks never use a)\n, as some might expect, deceived by the difference of our idiom, ‘it would have been natural for him to say,’ &c. [Goodwin's Gk. Moods and Tenses, § 49, 2=§ 415, ed. 1889.]
pare/xein To have brought him forward at the time, viz. as a ground for withdrawing the summons.

§§ 16, 17. Another proof of
Phormion's false hood is, that in his special plea against the suit I brought against him last year, he never pleaded payment. And yet the sole ground of my action was the report of Lampis that he had not paid, or put any goods on board.

e)nteqei=sqai In the middle sense, as is usual with the passive perfect of ti/qesqai and its compounds. [Infr. § 34 w(s e)nteqeime/nos. The perfect passive of ti/qhmi and its compounds is almost invariably borrowed from kei=mai, e.g. Plat. Leg. 793 B (no/mwn) tw=n e)n gra/mmasi teqe/ntwn te kai\ keime)nwn (not teqeime)nwn) kai\ tw=n e)/ti teqhsome/nwn. S.]
a)peilhfe/nai Lampis Phormion was the subject of the previous verb.

mh\ ga\r k.t.l. ‘For don't suppose I am so crazy, or, rather, so downright mad, as to put into writing such a charge as that, if Lampis had admitted that he had received the money; since I was sure to be refuted in my claim by him.’
[a)po/plhkton k.t.l., noted by Blass III i 581{2} as a peculiar expression, finds its parallel in the Meidias § 143 ou)x ou(/tws ei)mi\ a)/frwn ou)d' a)po/plhktos e)gw/. S.]
e)/mellon e)celegxqh/sesqai § 34.
paragrafh\n dido/nai A notable synonym of paragra/fesqai. [The Acc. and Dat. of paragrafh/ each occur twice within a few lines of one another.]

ou)k e)to/lmhsan This would have been the ordinary defence in a eu)qudiki/a, and was not a true ground for a paragrafh/
(§ 4), but it would have been an argument, if they could have pleaded it, in favour of the court granting a bar to the suit.

kai\ tau=ta § 50; 56 §§ 40, 44; cf. inf. § 33 kai\ tou=to. ‘And that too when I had expressly written in the charge against him, which you have just heard read, that he had neither put the goods on board nor paid the money.’ If he could have given so direct an answer to so direct a charge, he would have done so; not indeed as in itself sufficient as a bar to the suit (see supra on the Argument), but as an additional reason why it need not be tried.
perime/nein...ma/rtura Or. 56 § 30 p. th\n w(rai/an.]

§§ 18—20. When the suit last year was coming on, the defendants asked for an arbitration, to which I consented. Lampis, having no fear of being prosecuted for perjury before an arbitrator, and being bribed by Phormion, then said that Phormion had paid the money to him, though before he had denied it. When I confronted him with witnesses who heard him say he had not been paid by Phormion, he admitted he had said so, but pretended he didn't then know what he was saying.
mellou/shs The beginning of the second speech according to A. Schaefer. See note on § 21.
e)pitre/yai Cf. Or. 54 § 26.

i)sotelei= A privileged sojourner (denizen), i. e. a me/toikos who paid equal taxes with an a)sto/s, and no more. They
were specially exempted from the tax called metoi/kion. See F. A. Wolf, Pref. to Leptines (p. 27, Beatson), who remarks that this passage shows they were not wholly excluded from holding offices, as had been generally supposed. There is some depreciation of the position in § 44. [Gilbert, Gk. Const. Ant., p. 183 ET. A denizen could only act as a private arbitrator; Clerc, Métèques Ath., p. 180.]
a)sfale\s That there was no great danger of a prosecution. This is explained by ou) ga\r &c infra.——h)/dh, viz. as he was not now in court.
marturei=n o(/ ti bou/loito § 19 marturou=sin o(/ ti a)\n bou/lwntai. Various inflexions of marturei=n occur five times in these two §§ (Uhle, p. 18).]
merisa/menos Compare e)pei\ a)nekoinw/sato, § 12.

19 o(/moion—kai\ ‘The same as it is to do so before an arbitrator.’ It does not seem certain from this passage whether a man could not be prosecuted for perjury before an arbitrator. It may mean that in practice it was seldom done, and so the risk was not great.
ei)s ta\ u(me/tera pro/swpa k.t.l. 56 § 20 ou)de\n h(=tton tolma=| ble/pein ei)s ta\ u(me/tera pro/swpa.
u(po/keitai ‘Is in store,’ ‘is reserved for,’ ‘awaits’ [Lycurg. § 130 ei)dw\s u(pokeime/nhn au(tw| timwri/an.

tw=n e)c a)rxh=s Of those who had been present at the first interview (§ 11) between me and Lampis.——pare/xomai, as distinct from pare/xw, always contemplates the person from whom a thing comes, not to whom it is given. It is subjective, while the active is objective. Thus, e)gw) pare/xomai a)reth/n, ‘I show or exhibit virtue,’ but pare/xw soi xrh/mata, &c.
‘Producing witnesses’ implies that it was for the object and interest of the party producing them.

kata\ kra/tos luculenter et invicte (Reiske). Being convicted, in a way that he could not evade, of telling falsehoods.——[kata\ kra/tos is probably not found elsewhere with e)cele/gxesqai, which is usually coupled with adverbs such as periboh/tws or (more commonly) fanerw=s. S.]

ta\ yeudh= marturw=n The Article is omitted before yeudh= only where the latter is used in a predicative sense. Cf. 45 § 2, and Blass, Rheinisches Museum, XLIV 20. S.]—ponhro/s, ‘a fellow without principle,’ i.e. preferring ke/rdos to to\ di/kaion.

pro\s tou=ton There is some difficulty in this, first, as to taking it with w(molo/gei or with ei)rhke/nai, secondly, as to the person meant. It can hardly mean, as G. H. Schaefer, Voemel and Kennedy take it, the arbitrator Theodotus. It may mean Phormion, the defendant, if construed with ei)rhke/nai, but then we must assume that Phormion was also present at the interview, which is not stated in § 11. Or, possibly, if the deuterologi/a, or second partner's speech, commences at § 21, pro\s tou=ton may mean the other partner. The sense would then be, ‘Lampis admitted he had told my partner here (anonymous) that Phormion had not paid him.’ But this supposition is not without difficulty. [M. Dareste takes it of Chrysippus, whose brother, he considers, is now speaking. S.]
e)nto/s—au(tou= A favourite phrase with Lampis, §§ 35, 49. Cf. Antiphon 5 § 45 e)/ndon w)\n au(tou= (Blass III i 581{2}) and e)cesthke/nai in u(po/q. l. 25. S.]

§ 21. That the second speech begins here seems probable from ou)=tos in § 23, which appears to mean Chrysippus. If we could fix the division at § 18, then the tou=ton just discussed might equally mean Chrysippus. [G. H. Schaefer and Voemel think the second speech begins at § 22, e)c au)tou= dh\ tou= pra/gmatos. This seems not unlikely, as the second speaker would naturally commence with a brief summary of the facts that had been brought forward. The Zurich editors and A. Schaefer (Dem. u. s. Zeit III B 305) consider the second speech to begin at § 18, mellou/shs de\ th=s di/khs, and end with § 32. The latter view is followed by M. Dareste. Nitsche, dissert. de traiciendis partibus in Dem. or, Berlin, 1863 (quoted by Blass
III i 580{2}), assigns §§ 1—17, 30— 31, 44—52, to Chrysippus; and §§ 18—29, 32—33, to his brother. Thalheim assigns only §§ 18—29 to the brother. S.]

a)kou/sas k.t.l. ‘Theodotus, after several hearings, believing that Lampis was giving false evidence, did not acquit Phormion, but sent us to the court; for he did not like to decide against the defendant, being a friend or relation of his, as we afterwards heard; and he did not like to acquit him, that he might not break his own oath,’ viz. to decide according to the merits of the case.
ou)k a)pe/gnw th=s di/khs inf. a)pognw=nai th=s di/khs w/knei, and § 45.
a)fh=ken—ei)s to\ dikasth/rion § 45 gno/ntos tou= *qeodo/tou a)pie/nai h(ma=s ei)s to\ dikasth/rion.

§ 22. Now ask yourselves how he could have paid the money to Lampis. He left Athens without sufficient goods as a security, and additionally in debt to other lenders. At Bosporus the market was so dull, that he could hardly pay those who had lent him for the outer voyage only.
ou)k e)nqe/menos It is clear that the goods worth 5500 drachms in § 7 were purchased with the e)pidaneismoi/, and did not cover the loan of Chrysippus. See sup. on § 6.
toi=s e)moi=s xrh/masin The singular pronoun is here used by the partner who is actually speaking, though both partners are really concerned. Cf. § 31 e)moi\ tw=| danei/santi.
a)ph/llacen See note on Or. 36 § 25.

§ 23. ‘Phormion pretends to have paid a sum to Lampis which I can show to be more than he owed me at Athens; and therefore it is very improbable that he paid it.’ Again an argument e)k tw=n ei)ko/twn.

ou(=tos My partner Chrysippus.——disxili/as, cf. § 6, where the sum is called 20 minae. ——w(/ste, ‘on condition of receiving at Athens 2600 drachms.’ The interest therefore was very large, but so also was the risk considerable.

stath=ras Hesych. *kuzikhnikoi\ stath=res: diebebo/hnto w(s eu)= kexaragme/noi. pro/swpon de\ h)=n gunaiko\s o( tu/pos. [The ordinary gold stater weighed a double drachma of silver; and as, in the time of Menander, shortly after the date of this speech, the ratio of gold to silver had fallen from 13 1/3 to 10:1 (Pollux, ix 76), the value of this stater must have fallen to 20 dr. The Cyzicene stater was nearly twice as heavy, but, being of electrum, the value of the gold contained in it (3/4 or less) must have fallen to less than 30 dr.

The text informs us that its value at Bosporus was 28 Attic drachmae. “The weight of the Cyzicene stater is uniformly about 248 grains. As the Attic and Macedonian staters which weighed 133 grains were equivalent to 20 Attic drachmae, while the Cyzicene, weighing 248 grains, passed for no more than 28, it is evident that the silver alloy of the electrum of which those pieces are made was deducted and considered of no value, not being in fact worth the cost of extraction. Mr Burgon estimates the alloy of ancient electrum at about 1/4. Then as 133 is to 20, so is 3/4 of 248 or 186 to 28, exactly the equivalent in drachmae of the Cyzicene stater as given by Demosthenes.” Leake's Numismata Hellenica (Asiatic Greece), p. 50. A specimen may be seen in Leake's Collection at the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge, Div. II 21, and there are two others in Trin. Coll. Library. Their types vary, sometimes the head of a bull or lion, generally with a tunny-fish below; sometimes the head of Proserpine. See Plate of Coins, no. 6 and 7. Cf. Hesych. quoted above; Boeckh's Publ. Econ. bk. I, chap. v, notes 45— 50 Frànkel, and Head's Hist. Num. p. 450. S.]

daneisa/menos ‘By borrowing money (at Bosporus) on the interest paid for loans on land,’ i.e. on real security. This being e/fektos, i.e. a sixth part added to the sum lent (e.g. £70 for £60, or somewhat more than 16 per cent.), makes up the following sums; 120 staters = 3360 dr. = 33 min. 60 dr., which + in
terest at 1/6 or 560 amounts to 3920 dr. = 39 min. 20 dr.
e)/fektoi Harpocr. s. v. e)/fektos to/kos: o( e)pi\ tw=| e(/ktw| tou= kefalai/ou: *dhmosqe/nhs e)n tw=| u(pe\r *xrusi/ppou.

e)du/nato e)kei= This shows that the value of money differed, as with us, in different places. [Cf. Xenoph. de Vectig. III 2 kai\ oi( a)rgu/rion e)ca/gontes (e)k tw=n *)aqhnw=n) kalh\n e)mpori/an e)ca/gousin. o(/pou ga\r a)\n pwlw=sin au)to/, pantaxou= plei=on tou= a)rxai/ou lamba/nousin. K. F. Hermann, Privatalterthümer, § 47, 17 = p. 451 ed. Blumner. S.]
gi/gnontai .. gi/gnetai of numbers; Or. 56 § 41 of interest.]
su/mpan 56 § 15 su/nolon.

to/son kai\ to/son ‘Comes to so much, namely thirty-nine minas twenty drachms, which he does not here specify, because it is mentioned immediately after.’ Penrose. [Cf. Or. 57 § 29 e)/th to/sa kai\ to/sa: Hesych. h)\ tosau=ta. S.]

a)nti\ disxili/wn k.t.l. Instead of the sum he really owed. ——tria/konta k.t.l., the sum he pretended to have paid in staters, not including the interest. (He here expresses it not as 33 minae, but as 30 minae 300 drachmae, |&c.) [daneisa/menos must be taken absolutely, ‘in virtue of his loan,’ not as governing either to/kon, or the antecedent of a(/s. The latter has to mean ‘both which sums,’ i.e. the total of the principal and interest. S.]

trisxili/as e)nakosi/as ei)/kosin It will be observed that the interest (560 dr) on the sum borrowed at Bosporus, though really due to the lender there, is unfairly reckoned with the amount paid to Lampis as agent of Chrysippus. See A. Schaefer, Dem. u. s. Zeit, III B 306. S.]

e)co\n d' au)tw=| k.t.l. ‘And when he might have paid the money back at Athens after the double voyage, are we to believe that he paid it at Bosporus (i.e. as e(tero/plous), and too much by 13 minae?’ For he said he had paid 3920 instead of 2600, which is too much by 1320; or 13 minae 20 dr. In the reckoning by a round sum, he omits the 20 dr. See on Or. 37 § 50. For ple/on trisi\, ‘more by three,’ compare Thuc. I 36 fin. e)/cete pro\s au)tou\s plei/osi nausi\ tai=s h(mete/rais a)gwni/zesqai, i.e. ‘with a fleet the larger by the accession of our (the Corcyrean) ships.’ (Arnold here wrongly reads u(mete/rais, and Shilleto renders it ‘with a larger navy even ours.’)

[If Phormion's loan of 1000 dr. from Lampis (§ 6 fin.) was at the same interest as the 2000 dr. from Chrysippus (§ 23 init.) he would owe Lampis exactly 1300 dr. or 13 minae. It is therefore open to Phormion to reply that the alleged overpayment included the sum due to the skipper himself. S.]

§ 26. Another improbability. You found it difficult to pay the loan on the outer voyage only; and yet you pretend to have paid before the full time (and when there was no pressure on you for payment) the principal and the interest, and the penalty besides, when you were not bound to pay that at all.
prosh/dreuon Who kept close to you, and watched your proceedings. Cf. Lacrit. § 29 tou/tois prosh=|men kai\ a(/m' e)skopou=men k.t.l.

tw=| mh\ paro/nti Logically, tw=| ou) paro/nti is more correct; but there is a tendency to say o( mh\ parw
, because the formula generally refers to some indefinite person. Conversely, in Eur. Suppl. 227 qeo\s toi=s tou= nosou=ntos ph/masin diw/lese to
 ou) nosou=nta, we might have looked for to
 mh/, yet here there is a kind of attraction to what next follows, kou)de
 h)dikhko/ta. See on Or. 37 § 28 e)moi\ tw=| mh\ paro/nti, and ibid. § 25, and 57.

kai\ ta\ e)piti/mia ta\ e)k th=s suggrafh=s Compare 56 §§ 27, 44. He appears to call the 1320 drachms overpaid ‘the penalty,’ not in serious earnest, since it was not likely the sums would agree exactly. Phormion had incurred the penalty by not putting the goods on board as security; but no necessity was laid on him at the time for paying it. The amount mentioned in § 33 as a penalty for not shipping the goods according to the contract, is 5000 drachms, the risk being greater if there was no cargo.
ka)kei/nous The lenders of the money on the e(tero/plous agreement.

ou)k e)dedi/eis Phormion had paid these (at least the a)rxai=on, though not perhaps the interest, § 26), but mo/lis, perhaps after being ‘dunned’ and threatened. Cf. Or. 37 § 38 kai\ tau=t' a)peilhfo/ti gli/sxrws kai\ mo/lis para\ tou/tou. The sense is, ‘it was more likely that you would have been afraid of them, than that you would have had such special care for Chrysippus, whom you had wronged before you left the harbour.’—pra=cin, the right to enforce payment, by seizing your goods. Or. 56 §§ 35, 45.

kai\ nu=n k.t.l. Further arguments e)k tw=n ei)ko/twn. ‘At Athens, where the compact was made (and therefore where you can be sued at law), you don't scruple to defraud the lender, while at Bosporus, where you were not likely to be sued, you pretend to have paid more than was due.’ There is an assumption here of fraudulent intention in ou)k o)knei=s a)posterei=n, which is hardly fair.

kai\ oi( me
 a)/lloi ‘Most people, who borrow for the outward and homeward voyage, when about to sail from their respective ports, take care to have plenty of witnesses present, and call on them to attest that’ [contract being completed by the act of putting to sea] ‘the lender's risk begins from this moment’ (h)/dh). [Here the witnesses are witnesses to nothing
but the bare fact that such a ship put to sea at such a time; not to the borrowing as in § 30.] ‘And yet you rely (lit. lean) on a single witness, and that too one who has taken part in the wrong (Lampis); you did not make either my servant or my partner witnesses of the payment at Bosporus, nor deliver the letters to them with which we charged you, and in which a written order had been given that they were to follow you closely in whatever matter you might happen to be engaged.’ e(ni\ skh/ptei ma/rturi, cf. § 47 ou)=tos skh/ptetai ma/rturi.——to
 pai=da to
 h(me/teron, called to
 tou/tou in § 29, see sup. § 4.

e)pistola\s...e)peqh/kamen Harpocr. s.v. e)piqe/tous e(orta/s: le/gein ga\r h)=n ei)qisme/non e)pe/qhken e)pistolh\n a)nti\ tou= pare/dwken, w(s *dhmosqe/nhs e)n tw=| u(pe\r *xrusi/ppou pro\s th\n *formi/wnos paragrafh/n. Id. s.v. a)ntepiti/qhsin: a)nti\ tou= a/ntepiste/llei *)isai=os e)n tw=| pro\s *kallipi/dhn. Hdt. iii 42; v 95; Thuc. i 129 § 2; Ar. Poet. 16 § 8. S.]

prosh=ke/ ge Irony: ‘Surely, when he was paying back so large a sum of money, and even more than he had borrowed, he ought to have had it talked about on the Mart, and to have invited all men to witness the act, but above all the servant and partner of Chrysippus’ (sup. § 8).

§ 30. Continued irony: ‘men don't get more witnesses than is necessary to see that they borrow, but as many as they can to see that they pay, and that their honesty and respectability in their dealings may be talked about. How then was it that you acted so differently in the matter of your pretended payment?’
i)/ste—pa/ntes § 39 kai\ tau=ta pa/ntes i)/ste.
e)pieikei=s § 40 e)piei/keia. Or. 56 § 9 e/pieikw=s.
tou\s to/kous a)mfote/rous ‘The interest on both voyages, though you had used the money only for the outer voyage,’ and so might have employed it in some other investment till your return to Athens.

e(tero/plw| is rightly contracted, although the neut. pl. e(tero/ploa remains uncontracted in §§ 8, 22, 26, 40, cf. a)mfotero/ploa in § 28, and eu)/ploa and eu)/noa elsewhere. Kuhner-Blass Gr. Gr. I i 401.]

kai\ ei) tou=t' e)/pracas ‘And, if you had acted so,’ viz. had secured many witnesses, ‘no one of the trading merchants would have been more looked up to (for honesty) than you.’ The indefinite plei=n and oi( ple/ontes for ‘trading’ and ‘traders’ is to be noticed. So Ar. Pax 341 h)/dh ga e)ce/stai to/q' u(mi=n plei=n, me/nein, oi)/koi kaqeu/dein. Plat. Gorgias p. 467 D oi( ple/onte/s te kai\ to
 a)/llon xrhmatismo
 xrhmatizo/menoi. Dem. Or. 37 § 54 o(/stis de\ ei)/rgastai me
 w(/sper e)gw\ ple/wn kai\ kinduneu/wn.

su\ de\ k.t.l. ‘Whereas you, instead of making many persons witnesses of these acts, did all you could to escape observation! One would almost think you were doing something dishonest.’ The satire is very keen, and must have been effective as an answer to Phormion's pretences.

e)moi\ ‘To me in person,’ not to an agent, and for me. In that case, he says, you would have got the bond cancelled, and so have been rid of the
liability at once. ‘But, paying as you say you did, to an agent, at a distance, when the contract was with me and not with Lampis, and when the risk of a voyage was at hand, it seems that you never asked any one to be your witness; either slave or free.’ It does not appear from all this that a witness of the payment to an agent was legally necessary. A receipt of some kind would have been enough, probably. But Phormion appears to have thought that his bare assertion would be accepted by the court.

a)nelo/menos Lit. ‘taking up (or ‘getting back,’ Mr Mayor p. 242) the bond deposited against you.’ Kennedy translates, ‘you would have taken up the agreement and got rid of the obligation.’ The active in the sense of ‘destroying,’ ‘cancelling,’ occurs in § 33 kai\ tou=t' a)nh|rhkw\s au)to/s. In Or. 48 § 46 we read e)xrh=n ga\r au)to\n—paralabo/nta pollou\s ma/rturas a)ciou=n a)nairei=sqai ta\s sunqh/kas para\ tou= *)androklei/dou. And Or. 33 § 12 e)nanti/on pollw=n martu/rwn ta\s suggrafa\s a)neilo/meqa.

tw=| nauklh/rw| There seems to have been a clause in the bond to the effect that, if Phormion should be detained in Bosporus, he should pay the money to the skipper; or, as Kennedy suggests, that he should have the option of so paying it, if he did not choose to ship the goods.

oi(/de The partners here present. This is certainly obscure. The speech commences in the plural, di/kaia dehso/meqa &c, but in § 6 Chrysippus speaks for himself, e)gw\ ga\r k.t.l., and in § 21 the other partner, who is generally supposed to be still addressing the court. It would seem therefore that several were concerned in the loan to Phormion; for no account is here taken of the e)pidaneismoi/. [Blass III i 581{2}, referring oi(/de to the two partners, holds that the speech was origi
nally written for a third person, and afterwards imperfectly revised for delivery by Chrysippus himself; ou)=tos, applied to Chrysippus, being repeatedly left unaltered §§ 20, 23, 29, 32.] Again, the du/o suggrafa\s is obscure. Penrose thinks it only means that two copies were made. It is evidently spoken of as an additional security; and perhaps it means that each of the principal partners had his own bond against Phormion.

w(s a)
 k.t.l. Supply dra/saien. So Mid. § 14 kai\ qo/rubon kai\ kro/ton toiou=ton w(s a)
 e)painou=nte/s te kai\ sunhsqe/ntes e)poih/sate. Thuc. I 33 w(s a)
 ma/lista met' a)eimnh/stou marturi/ou th
 xa/rin kataqh(sesqe (kataqei=sqe and kataqh=sqe are mistakes resulting from ignorance of the idiom).

mo/nos mo/nw| A forcible and idiomatic collocation (like polla\ polloi=s, pa=si pa/ntws, &c); oftener found in such contexts than the simple mo/nos. [As an instance of the former we have De Cor. p. 273, 1 tw=| u(po\ tw=n polemi/wn pemfqe/nti mo/nos mo/nw| sunh/|ei, of the latter Fals. Leg. p. 430, 22 ou)damou= mo/nous e)ntugxa/nein *fili/ppw| which Cobet (Variae Lectiones, p. 112) would alter into mo/nous mo/nw|. Shilleto however quotes passages from the poets which do not admit of such alteration, e.g. Ar. Pax 660 h( d: a)lla) pro\s se smikro\n ei)pa/tw mo/non (v. Journ. of Class. and Sacred Philol. IV 310). S.]—kata\ sou=, i.e. a)ll' ou) kata\ *la/mpidos.—pro\s tou=ton, with Chrysippus.

§§ 33—5. Phormion pleads, as a bar to the suit, that the payment was conditional, and not binding on him if the ship should be wrecked. The reply is, that this non-payment is again conditional on the goods being put on board, which was not done. Therefore the actual wreck is no release from liability.

swqei/shs th=s new\s Emphatic, as the condition of a)podou=nai. Or. 32 § 5 ou)sw=n tw=n suggrafw=n w(/sper ei)w/qasin a(/pasai, swqei/shs th=s new\s a)podou=nai ta\ xrh(mata. Or. 56 § 31.—kai\ ga\r k.t.l. ‘very true; for it also bids you,’ &c.— pentakisxili/as, a very heavy e)piti/mion (§ 26), and nearly double the amount due with interest (2600 dr., § 23). Kennedy thinks this was the penalty to which Phormion was bound, in case he neither shipped the goods at Bosporus nor paid the stipulated sum to Lampis. This he accounts for by the increased risk incurred by the lenders through the doubtful respecta
bility of Lampis, who though he resided at Athens was a foreigner by extraction.

su\ de\ k.t.l. You take exception to, or do not admit, this clause, viz. ordering you to ship the goods, and yet found an objection to my claims on the phrase swqei/shs th=s new/s, though you have yourself made the phrase null and void by not shipping the goods from Bosporus. Of course, the exemption from payment in the event of a wreck depended solely, in equity, on the heavy loss of the borrower's goods.
tou=to...th=s suggrafh=s 56 § 38 au)to\ tou=to th=s s.

o(po/te ga(r k.t.l. Dum dicis. A causal use of o(po/te, when time is not considered, but simply the allegation of a fact. So o(/pou is used inf. § 45. Or. 41 § 25 o(po/te ga\r kai\ no/mous e)/xw pare/xesqai,—ti/ dei= makrw=n e)/ti lo/gwn; Compare also Or. 56 § 13, and o(phni/ka in Mid. § 42. Xen. Conviv. II § 12 ou)/toi tou/s ge qewme/nous ta/de a)ntile/cein e)/ti oi)/omai w(s ou)xi\ kai\ h( a)ndrei/a didakto/n, o(po/te au(/th kai/per gunh( ou)=sa ou(/tw tolmhrw=s ei)s ta\ ei/fh i(/etai. [Goodwin, Moods and Tenses, § 713, 1889.]

to\ me\n prw=ton ‘The contract ordered him to put the goods on board, which he did once pretend to have done; only, knowing that he was sure to be detected, he changed his story and pretended that he paid the amount to Lampis in gold.’ Penrose.—[w(/rmhsen implies precipitancy; he rashly ventured on a plea which he was forth with obliged to withdraw. F. H. Baynes.]

e)llimenistai=s ‘The harbourmasters,’ who had to see that
no vessels cleared out without paying duty. Cf. § 7. [Bekker's Anecd. 251 e)nlimenistai/ (sic) : oi( e)n toi=s lime/si telw=nai. Gilbert, Gk. Const. Ant. p. 350 ET. S.]

metaballo/menos k.t.l. ‘Then he changes his tack, conspires with Lampis to defraud me, and says he paid him in money.’ Both words are emphatic; ‘he no longer says he put the goods on board, but that he placed the amount in his hands to give to Chrysippus.’

e)fo/dion A support to his plea; skh=yin, pro/fasin. [For this rare metaphorical use of e)fo/dion, cf. Hyperides Eux. col. xxxi 15 e)fo/dion e(autw=| ei)s to\n a)gw=na to\ e)kei/nhs o)/noma parafe/rwn. S.]

ou)k a)
 h(gou/menos i.e. o(/ti ou)k a)
 &c, ‘thinking that we (here at Athens) would not find it easy to get to the truth respecting transactions that had passed between themselves alone.’ Like ou) fhmi/, ou) dokw= &c, ou)x h(gou=mai means ‘I think not,’ and the a)
 follows the ou)k by the usual attraction, though its force is exerted on e)le/gcai.— o(/sa pra/ceian, quae ipsi inter se fecissent.
pri\n—diafqarh=nai § 41.
ou)k e)nto\s w)\n cf. § 20.
e)meri/sato See § 18.——mnhmoneu/ein, like the convenient memory of Strepsiades in Ar. Nub. 485 e)a\n d' o)fei/lw, sxe/tlios, e)pilh/smwn pa/nu.

§ 36. The conduct of Lampis has been such that the public have been wronged as well as myself. He has fraudulently availed himself of the remission of the corn-duty to convey corn from Bosporus to Macedonia.
deino/tera pe/praktai § 45 pa/qoimi [ta\] deino/tata.
pe/praktai au)tw=| The usual construction with this passive perfect (or aorist). It is a very common use with Demosthenes. [See note on Ol. 1 § 28, p. 155, ed. Sandys.]

kh(rugma ga\r—e)ca/gein [In the speech against the law of Leptines for abolishing a)te/leia, or exemption from taxes and burdensome duties in reward for important services to the state, Demosthenes dwells at length on the benefits conferred on Athens by Leucon king of Bosporus, who had himself received this a)te/leia with the citizenship, and had signally assisted the Athenian importation of the corn of the Euxine by exempting from tolls all vessels bound for Athens, and by giving public notice that they should be freighted before all others (§ 31 to\n *leu/kwna toi=s a)/gousin *)aqh/naze a)te)leian dedwke)nai kai\ khru/ttein prw/tous gemi/zesqai tou\s w(s h(ma=s ple)ontas). Leucon after reigning from 393 to 353 B.C. was succeeded by his sons Spartocus and Paerisades. The latter (who soon became sole king) is described in the present passage as granting a privilege to the Athenian corn-trade (a)telh= to\n si=ton e)ca/gein) similar to that granted by his father Leucon. In 347—6 honours were paid by Athens to Spartocus and Paerisades, because of their promise e)pimelh(sesqai th=s e)kpomph=s tou= si/tou (Hicks, Gk. Hist. Inscr., p. 189 = Dittenberger, Sylloge, no. 101). By a proposal of Demosthenes himself a bronzestatue of Paerisades was set up in the market-place of Athens (Dinarchus I 43, p. 95). His reign ended in 310 B.C. S.]
*pairisa/dou See § 8 n.

e)pidhmw=n k.t.l. ‘Lampis, happening then to be at Bosporus, obtained the permission to export corn, and also the remission of duty in the name of the state. And so he loaded a large ship with corn, but took it to Acanthus (in Chalcidice) and there disposed of it [as the partner of Phormion, at our expense’]. He regards it as an aggravation of the offence, that a privilege granted to Athens was used for a contraband transaction.—See Boeckh, P. Econ. p. 85 Lewis (2), p. 118 Lamb.

e)/labe This verb seems adapted to thn a)te/leian rather than to th(n e)cagwgh/n. [It was as an ‘Athenian’ that Lampis secured not only the permission to export at all, but also the privilege of doing so duty free.] In Lept. § 31 Dem. remarks that Athens depended more than any other state on its importation of corn, plei/stw| tw=n pa/ntwn a)nqrw/pwn h(mei=s e)peisa/ktw| si/tw| xrw/meqa.

p.title: Further aggravations of the offence. Lampis had a residence at Athens, and the time was one of special scarcity, so that every cargo that could be had, was wanted at Athens.

div2.p: tw=n no/mwn—e)mpo/rion [Cf. Or. 35 § 50, Lycurgus adv. Leocratem 27 oi( u(me/teroi no/moi ta\s e)sxa/tas timwri/as o(ri/zousin, e)a/n tis *)aqhnai/wn a)/llose/ poi sithgh/sh| h)\ w(s u(ma=s, cf. Or. 58 § 12 pleu/santa dikai/ws oi( prosh=ken, and 56 § 6. S.]

diemetrou=nto ‘Were having measured out to them their barley-meal in the Odeum, while those in the Peiraeus (contrasted with to\ a)/stu) were getting their loaves by pennyworths at a time in the arsenal and their barley-meal at the long warehouse, having it doled out to them at a gallon a-piece, and nearly trampled to death in the crush.’ A curious picture of corn at famine price. [A. Schaefer places this time of high prices in the period between 330 and 326 B.C. when Demosthenes was sitw/nhs. Dem. u. s. Zeit III 268—271{1}, 294— 8{2}; III B 300, 339. Cf Blass, Att. Ber. III 516{1}, 578{2}. S.]

e)n tw=| newri/w| ‘in the dockyard’; doubtless in some open place in front of it (Wachsmuth, Stadt Athen II i 51 f., where Milchhofer's suggestion e)mpori/w| is rejected). The term is used in sing. in 47 §§ 20, 23, and in 50 § 36. S.]

e)n tw=| w)|dei/w| The Odeum of Pericles was a music school or minor theatre, lying east of the great theatre under the Acropolis, and sometimes (Ar. Vesp. 1109) used as a law court. The present passage shows that it was made generally useful. [Or. 59 § 52 laxo/ntos di/khn si/tou ei/s w)|dei=on and Pollux VIII 33. Cf. Bekker's Anecd. 317 w)|dei=on: qe/atron *)aqh/nh|sin, o(\ pepoi/hke *periklh=s ei)s to\ e)pidei/knusqai tou\s mousikou/s: e)n w(=| kai\ dikasth/rion h)=n si/tou kai\ a)/lfita diemetrei=to e)kei=. Miss Harrison's Ancient Athens p. 261—3. S.]

The makra\ stoa\ was used as a cornstore. It is mentioned in Ar. Ach. 548, as in a state of activity during preparation for war, stoa=s stenaxou/shs, siti/wn metroume)nwn. [Schol. th=s legome/nhs a)lfitopw/lidos h(\n w)|kodo/mhse *periklh=s o(/pou kai\ si=tos a)pe/keito th=s po/lews. h)=n de\ peri\ to\n *peiraia=.
